greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of narrowly totally strongly normal integer partitions of n.
comment: A partition is narrowly totally strongly normal if either it is empty, a singleton (narrow), or it covers an initial interval of positive integers (normal) and has weakly decreasing run-lengths (strong) that are themselves a narrowly totally strongly normal partition.
example: The a(1) = 1, a(2) = 2, a(3) = 3, and a(55) = 4 partitions:

For example, starting with the partition (3,3,2,2,1) and repeatedly taking run-lengths gives (3,3,2,2,1) -> (2,2,1) -> (2,1) -> (1,1) -> (2). The first four are normal and have weakly decreasing run-lengths, and the last is a singleton, so (3,3,2,2,1) is counted under a(11).
xref: The non-totally normal version is A316496.
The widely alternating version is A332292.
The non-strong case of compositions is A332296.
The case of compositions is A332336.
The wide version is a(n) - 1 for n > 1.
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Feb 15 2020
